Climate change will increase the variability of global crop yields. This study quantifies the magnitude of this increase. We find that the coefficient of variation of maize yields will increase to values much larger than present-day values in most of the world. This increase is due to both an increase in the standard deviation of yields and a decrease in mean yields. Our results portend rising instability in global grain trade and international grain prices, affecting especially the 800 million people living in extreme poverty who are most vulnerable to food price spikes. They also underscore the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The extent to which large herbivore assemblages partition food resources is largely unknown. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant species of large mammal herbivore in semiarid African savanna. We found that, despite being similar in body size, most species were dissimilar in diet. Moreover, species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption had the greatest dietary overlap. These results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large herbivore assemblages. Our findings highlight the importance of diet composition in determining trophic interactions. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a devastating impact on small businesses. We survey more than 5,800 small businesses in the United States. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed. Many businesses are financially fragile. Many businesses expect the crisis to last for many months. Many businesses expect to apply for the CARES Act programs, but anticipate problems with the programs.

This is due to the selective removal of small plastic fragments by the ocean interior. This sink may be of global scale and may be of fundamental importance to understand the fate of the missing plastic debris.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950. This expansion has been driven by the motorized fleet, particularly the powered-artisanal fleet. The ability to reproduce is a fundamental characteristic of all organisms. In this study, we investigate the factors that limit reproductive output in mammals. We find that the most important factor is the mother’s metabolic power. This finding has implications for the evolution of reproduction and the domestication of animals.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder. The cytopathological hallmark of MSA is the accumulation of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected oligodendrocytes. Several studies point to α-syn oligomerization and aggregation as a mediator of neurotoxicity in synucleinopathies including MSA. We present here an in vivo proof of concept of the ability of the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 to mitigate α-syn pathology and to mediate neuroprotection in a mouse model of MSA. Our results suggest that VX-765, a drug that was well tolerated in a 6 wk-long phase II trial in patients with epilepsy, is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. VX-765 could be a potential therapeutic option for MSA. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels. It is the most abundant cell type in the body and is responsible for many important functions, including controlling blood pressure, hemostasis, and inflammation. The endothelium is composed of thousands of cells that are connected by a network. The network is critical for the endothelium to communicate with the rest of the body. The network is also critical for the endothelium to control its own functions. This study reveals the nature of the endothelial network. COVID-19 has become a global pandemic. The pandemic has been accompanied by a large body of research, policy, and public health activity. However, there is a need for data to support this activity. We have created a data source that provides a wide range of data on COVID-19 activity. This data source is available to the public through an API.

Potassium channels are important for the normal functioning of the nervous and muscular systems. They are also involved in a variety of diseases. The selectivity filter and the activation gate are functionally and structurally coupled. The selectivity filter is closed in the closed state and opens upon channel activation. We have identified the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. We show that this residue is essential for the structural coupling between the activation gate and the selectivity filter. This work provides a structural basis for the functional coupling between activation and inactivation. It also provides a structural explanation for the lack of C-type inactivation gating in some K+ channel mutants. Finally, it provides a structural explanation for the structural collapse of the selectivity filter in the closed state. This work may lead to the development of new drugs for the treatment of some diseases.

Anxiety is a common feature of psychiatric disorders. However, the underlying mechanisms are not fully understood. Here we show that high-anxious rats are prone to become subordinate in a social dominance test. We further show that this is due to a reduced mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. This is a key region for the establishment of social hierarchy and is critically involved in the low social competitiveness associated with high anxiety. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. The design of multifunctional structures with complex shapes and extreme responses is highly desired for various applications. However, the use of a single material phase and heuristically developed structural patterns leads to restricted design space and potential failure to achieve specific target behaviors. Here, we propose a free-form inverse design approach to synthesize multiple hyperelastic materials with distinct properties into composite structures. The structures exhibit organic shapes and motions with irregular distributions of material phases. Within the structures, different materials play distinct roles yet seamlessly collaborate through sophisticated deformation mechanisms to produce the target behaviors. The synthesized structures are effectively manufactured via multimaterial fabrication and highly nonlinear responses are physically and accurately realized in experiments. The proposed strategy can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications. This article is protected by copyright. Hemoglobin is the oxygen-binding protein of red blood cells. The hemoglobin expression pattern is regulated by the transcription factor BCL11A. In this study, we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is a key player in the regulation of hemoglobin expression in humans. IGF2BP1 is expressed in the fetus and is down-regulated in the adult. We show that IGF2BP1 is a key player in the regulation of hemoglobin expression in humans. IGF2BP1 mediates posttranscriptional loss of BCL11A, a key regulator of hemoglobin expression. These results suggest a mechanism for chronoregulation of fetal and adult hemoglobin expression in humans. This mechanism may be relevant for the development of hemoglobinopathies. Cancer is a leading cause of death worldwide. The development of new therapeutic strategies is urgently needed. In this study, we found that inhibition of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis sensitizes cancer cells to ferroptosis induction. Mechanistically, this resistance requires sustained activation of mTORC1 and the mTORC1-dependent induction of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. In conclusion, our findings suggest that combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction may be a promising strategy for cancer therapy. This strategy may be applicable to other forms of regulated necrosis. (Read more)

Hypertension is the most common cause of heart failure. The treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of the treatment of heart failure. The most common drugs for treating hypertension are calcium channel blockers. These drugs are associated with a higher risk of heart failure. Our study shows that these drugs promote vascular remodeling. This is a new mechanism of action of these drugs.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy for the conservation of biodiversity in the United States. It was science-based, incorporated adaptive management, and was the first to require the monitoring of biodiversity. We show that the NWFP has not yet been successful in reversing the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations. Our results highlight the need to continue to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and to ensure that the creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is a major challenge. We present a rational design approach to identify new antibiotics. We show that our approach is successful in identifying compounds that are active against antibiotic-resistant pathogens. The approach is based on computational predictions of membrane permeability, binding affinity to the ribosome, and solubility. The best compound identified by us is up to 56 times more active than telithromycin, a clinically used antibiotic. The approach is applicable to other antibiotic resistance problems.

Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often large, which makes them difficult to train and apply in practice. Here, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters. The network architecture is simple and easy to implement, train, and apply in practice.

The evolution of the African Great Lakes is a key process in the development of the continent and its biota. We present a continuous record of the hydroclimate of the region over the last 1.3 My. The record shows a dramatic shift in the effective moisture of the region at the MPT, which is consistent with global climate change. The record also shows that the evolution of the African Great Lakes is a key process in the development of the continent and its biota. The record provides a unique insight into the evolution of the Lake Malawi cichlid fish species flock. The evolution of the species flock is a key process in the development of the species and is a key part of the evolution of the cichlid family.

The use of electronic devices before bedtime is widespread in the United States and around the world. However, the biological effects of such devices on sleep have not been systematically studied. Here we show that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device before bedtime suppresses melatonin, phase-delays the circadian clock, and reduces the next-morning alertness. These effects may have important implications for performance, health, and safety.

The Younger Dryas cooling is a 1,300-y period of abrupt climate change. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the YD cooling. However, the origin of the bolide remains unknown. We report the results of a comprehensive study of osmium isotopes in sediments and magnetic grains from the YD sites in the United States and Belgium. The results are consistent with a terrestrial origin of the osmium. The spherules from the YD site in Pennsylvania are also consistent with a terrestrial origin. These results support the hypothesis that a bolide impact triggered the YD cooling. (Read more)

CTLA-4 is a key regulator of immune responses. However, its specific role in the development of autoimmunity is not fully understood. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in adult mice. We also show that CTLA-4 deficiency has opposing effects on different autoimmune models. Thus, CTLA-4 deficiency affects both central and peripheral tolerance. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Beetles are the most speciose group of animals. However, the origin of beetles and their diversification remain poorly understood. We reconstructed the evolutionary history of beetles using 154 genomes and 4,818 genes. Our results show that beetles diversified in the presence of angiosperms and that plant cell wall-degrading enzymes may have been key to the evolution of specialized plant-feeding habits. The ability of antibodies to recognize and neutralize viruses is a fundamental principle of the immune system. However, antibodies can mutate and lose their ability to neutralize viruses. This can lead to the emergence of new variants that are resistant to existing antibodies. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that can be used to optimize the structure of antibodies to improve their ability to neutralize viruses. We demonstrate the utility of this algorithm by improving the neutralizing activity of an antibody that is effective against multiple SARS-CoV-2 variants but not the most recent variant, Delta. Our algorithm can potentially be used to optimize other antibodies and other proteins, such as vaccines, to improve their ability to neutralize viruses. This could lead to the development of new antibody drug candidates that can be used to treat current and emerging viral infections. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of intense debate. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We find that larger populations do not enhance CCE. This finding is contrary to the predictions of some of the most influential models of CCE. However, we find that the CCE of technology is not enhanced by larger populations because participants in larger populations have access to more variation in plane performance. This variation may have overwhelmed participants’ working memory and weakened their ability to selectively copy the best-adapted plane(s). Our results have implications for the evolution of technology and human culture.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia. The strongest genetic risk factor influencing susceptibility to AD is the APOE gene. APOE isoform is associated with a 12-fold increased risk for AD in presence of two copies of the APOE4 allele. APOE is also involved in the clearance of synapses, which are the main sites of neurodegeneration in AD. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. We also suggest a hypothesis for the origin of the increased AD risk of the APOE4 allele. This hypothesis is based on the observation that APOE4 increases the accumulation of senescent synapses in the brain, which are more vulnerable to complement-mediated neurodegeneration. This study provides a new perspective on the role of APOE in AD pathophysiology. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The Earth's inner core is a solid sphere with a diameter of 2,890 km. It is the densest part of the planet. The formation mechanism of the inner core is still a mystery. The required degree of undercooling to nucleate the inner core is a key factor in solving the paradox. We found that the nucleation of the body-centered cubic phase is more likely to occur than that of the hexagonal close-packed phase. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the paradox. The two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core also opens an avenue for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the present inner core. This article is protected by copyright. Marijuana is the most widely used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are less clear. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced reactivity of the brain to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA). Specifically, marijuana abusers show reduced decreases in brain DA responses to methylphenidate. These findings suggest that chronic marijuana use is associated with decreased brain reactivity to DA stimulation. This might contribute to the negative emotionality and addictive behaviors of marijuana abusers. These findings also highlight the need to investigate the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Language is the defining cognitive ability of the human species. Yet, despite its importance, the neural mechanisms of language comprehension remain poorly understood. Here, we show that deep learning models that predict well from many different perspectives also predict neural responses to sentences in humans. This suggests that predictive processing may be a fundamental mechanism of sentence comprehension in the human brain. We also find that model architecture is a strong predictor of neural fit. These results provide computational evidence for the role of predictive processing in sentence comprehension. They also provide a new resource for understanding the neural mechanisms of language. This resource is available to the community at large.

Deep learning is a powerful machine learning paradigm that has recently achieved unprecedented success. However, it is still unclear why deep learning works so well. In this paper, we show that the instability of deep learning is closely related to the difficulty of solving ill-posed problems. We prove that deep learning is unstable for certain ill-posed problems. This explains why deep learning is unstable and why it is difficult to train deep networks to solve ill-posed problems. Our results also provide a classification theory for the stability of deep learning.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors. One of the most prominent is the failure of people to understand exponential growth. This failure is often attributed to a classic experiment published 45 years ago. However, the experiment’s design flaws were not noticed at the time. This article discusses the flaws and their consequences.

Leprosy is a disease that has been studied for centuries. It is caused by two bacteria, Mycobacterium leprae and Mycobacterium lepromatosis. The latter is associated with a reactional state known as Lucio's phenomenon. We sequenced the genome of M. lepromatosis from a Mexican patient. We found that M. lepromatosis and M. leprae have diverged from a common ancestor approximately 14 Mya. This suggests that the two bacteria are remarkably conserved despite causing different diseases. Entanglement and entropy are key concepts in quantum mechanics. They are also fundamental to the understanding of the emergence of thermodynamics. However, the dynamics of these quantities is still a matter of debate. Here, we show that the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit can be completely understood in terms of quasiparticles. This result is a major step toward a deeper understanding of the dynamics of entanglement and entropy.

COVID-19 is a global pandemic. The only available vaccine is based on the SARS-CoV-2 wild-type virus. We developed a vaccine based on a temperature-sensitive mutant of the same virus. The vaccine is easy to manufacture and can be stored at room temperature. It is highly protective in animal models.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history. The Second Pandemic (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of the disease is still debated. Here, we propose a model for plague transmission by human ectoparasites. We show that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death. This has important implications for the control of the disease.

The evolution of brain size is a well-known topic in comparative neurobiology. However, the evolution of brain neuronal density is still poorly understood. We present a comprehensive dataset of neuron numbers in amniotes and use it to reconstruct the evolution of brain neuronal density. We show that the evolution of brain neuronal density is different in reptiles, birds, and mammals. This has important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition.

Cancer is a complex disease with multiple causes and mechanisms. The identification of molecular targets that can be manipulated to treat cancer is a major goal of cancer research. TRAP1 (TNF receptor-associated protein) is a mitochondrial molecular chaperone that is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the utility of TRAP1 as a target has been questioned because of the difficulty in distinguishing between TRAP1 and HSP90, the other member of the HSP90 family of molecular chaperones. We have shown that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. These data suggest that TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor. Actin filaments are the main cytoskeletal elements in cells. They are dynamic polymers that can be assembled and disassembled. The disassembly process is controlled by the actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) protein family. ADF proteins are the main regulators of actin filament disassembly. However, how they do so remains unclear. Here, we use single-molecule and single-filament techniques to study the action of ADF proteins in different mechanical situations. We find that ADF proteins enhance severing of filaments under mechanical stress. This is a surprising result, because it is generally believed that mechanical stress hinders severing. Our results have important implications for understanding the role of ADF proteins in cells. They also provide a mechanism for understanding the role of ADF proteins in the assembly and disassembly of actin filaments in cells.

Fructose is the most common sweetener in the Western diet. However, the effects of fructose on brain and behavior are unknown. We show that fructose relative to glucose results in greater brain activation of reward-related regions and greater hunger and desire for food. These findings suggest that fructose may promote feeding behavior. Our results have implications for understanding the role of fructose in the development of obesity and its comorbidities. Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean. It is the only island in the world where the Austronesian language family is spoken. The island is also the only place where the Bantu language family is spoken. This paper provides a comprehensive view of the genetic diversity of the Malagasy people. We find that the Malagasy people are a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations. The settlement history of Madagascar is also discussed. We find that the settlement of Madagascar was not a single event but rather a series of events. This is important because it suggests that the island was not already populated when the first people arrived. We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions expressed by others on Facebook. This is a form of emotional contagion. We show that this occurs even when people do not interact in person. We also show that people’s own emotions are influenced by the emotions expressed by others. This is a form of emotional influence. These findings have implications for our understanding of the spread of emotions in society.

The ribosome is the site of protein synthesis in cells. The decoding of messenger RNA (mRNA) codons into amino acids is a fundamental step in protein synthesis. The presence of mRNA modifications can alter the decoding process. Here, we show that the presence of a common modification, pseudouridine (Ψ), can modestly alter the decoding of mRNA codons. Our work suggests that the presence of Ψ in mRNA can alter the rate of protein synthesis. This may have implications for the study of protein synthesis and the development of new therapeutics. The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is fundamental to human flourishing. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes in older age. These associations are robust to a range of potential confounders and are not explained by factors such as socioeconomic status, depressive symptoms, or health. These findings have implications for the design of interventions to promote healthy aging.

The evolution of body size is a central question in biology. Here, we show that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving the evolution of larger body sizes in four of the five extant aquatic mammal lineages. This result is consistent with the energetic constraints of the aquatic environment. Our results have implications for the evolution of body size in other aquatic and terrestrial organisms.

The common cold is one of the most common reasons for seeking medical attention. The mechanisms that determine the temperature dependence of rhinovirus replication are not well understood. We show that mouse airway cells replicate rhinovirus more efficiently at 37 °C, the core body temperature, than at 33 °C, the temperature found in the nasal cavity. This temperature-dependent growth phenotype is dependent on the antiviral defense response of the host cell. These findings have implications for the development of antiviral therapies for the common cold. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a major cause of infections in humans and animals. It is an opportunistic pathogen that can cause severe diseases in immunocompromised individuals. The bacterium is able to cause infections in the human body by secreting a variety of virulence factors. The mechanisms that allow the pathogen to cause infections are not fully understood. Here we show that P. aeruginosa uses its surface-adhesion system to sense the mechanical activity of its pili. This sensing system is important for the regulation of the expression of virulence factors. Our results provide a mechanistic understanding of how bacteria can sense their environment. This may lead to the development of new strategies to combat infections caused by this pathogen. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the last decades. This has led to a substantial contamination of surface waters. However, the consequences of this contamination for aquatic biodiversity are still unknown. We provide a comprehensive analysis of the global occurrence of pesticides in surface waters. We show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human society. The virus has spread to all continents and has infected more than 250 million people worldwide. The virus has also spread to animals, including free-living animals such as deer. We report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living deer. This discovery has important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic. We also highlight the need for a “One Health” approach to study the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a global problem. This paper examines the causes of this problem and the consequences of building large dams in developing countries. We also propose solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) and tau proteins in the brain. The exact mechanisms underlying the development of AD are not fully understood. In this study, we show that neurons are the main source of inflammatory factors in the brain. This finding may help to understand the disease and to develop new therapeutic strategies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The domestic chicken is one of the most widespread and important domesticated species. Its use in the economy is a recent phenomenon, which only became widespread in the last 2,000 y. The earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens is known from the Hellenistic period in the Southern Levant. We present a detailed analysis of the faunal assemblage from the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, and show that the exploitation of chickens was widespread and practiced on a large scale. This evidence is supported by a survey of the Southern Levant, which shows a sharp increase in the frequency of chicken during the Hellenistic period. We suggest that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later. This process may have been facilitated by the availability of chickens in the region. (Read more)

The folding of proteins is a major unsolved problem in biology. The folding of large proteins is especially difficult to study. Here, we report the results of a detailed study of the folding of the maltose binding protein. We show that the folding of this protein is a multistep process. The folding intermediates are native-like. The folding intermediates are not the same for all proteins. The folding intermediates are important for understanding the folding of other proteins.

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been shown to be a key mechanism of stress adaptation in bacteria. However, the cellular response to this accumulation is not well understood. Here, we show that the RNA pyrophosphohydrolase RppH, which is known to dephosphorylate Np4-capped RNAs, also deprotects Np4-capped RNAs. This enzyme has a unique mechanism for recognizing 5′ termini, which results in a one-nucleotide shift in the specificity of the substrate. This shift is critical for the subsequent deprotection of the 5′ terminus, which is required for the rapid degradation of the RNA. Our findings have implications for the mechanisms of stress adaptation and the regulation of gene expression. (Read more)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality. The mechanisms involved in the immunosuppression that occurs during sepsis are not fully understood. We demonstrated that arginine, a key amino acid in the immune system, is depleted during sepsis. We also showed that citrulline, a metabolite of arginine, is more effective than arginine in restoring T cell function and proliferation. These results provide evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. This strategy could be extended to other immune-related diseases. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. The Amazon is the world’s most important tropical forest. It is also one of the most threatened. The forest is being deforested at an unprecedented rate. The ability of antibodies to recognize and neutralize viruses is a fundamental principle of the immune system. However, antibodies can mutate and lose their ability to neutralize viruses. This can lead to the emergence of new variants that are resistant to existing antibodies. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that can be used to optimize the structure of antibodies to improve their ability to neutralize viruses. We demonstrate the utility of our approach by optimizing an antibody that is effective against multiple SARS-CoV-2 variants but not the most recent variant, Delta. Our optimized antibody is ∼10- to 600-fold more potent against SARS-CoV-2 variants, including Delta. Our approach can potentially be used to optimize other proteins, such as vaccines, to improve their ability to protect against emerging variants. This could lead to the development of new vaccines and antibody drug candidates. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Crop experts are the eyes and ears of farmers. They provide information on the status of crops, which is critical for farmers to make decisions on crop management. However, the information provided by crop experts is often qualitative and subjective. We show that this information can be transformed into a continuous probabilistic variable that is more suitable for quantitative analysis. We also show that the information provided by crop experts is stable over time and across crops. Finally, we demonstrate how this information can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official forecasts released midseason. Our results have implications for the design of agricultural monitoring systems.

Language is a complex cognitive ability that is essential for human communication. It is also a highly plastic system that is subject to change across the lifespan. Here we propose a computational model of language processing that is based on the idea that memory is maintained through adaptive changes in neuronal excitability. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can support the binding of linguistic features over time. Our model provides a neurobiological substrate for the processing of language. It may also be relevant to other forms of temporal integration in the brain.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, but its response to climate change remains uncertain. We synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types. Our results demonstrate that rising global temperatures may result in regionally variable responses in soil respiration, with colder climates being considerably more responsive to increased ambient temperatures compared with warmer regions. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The origin of plastids and their evolution during the transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle are still debated. Here, we present a model of the trajectory of plastid genome evolution during this process. We show that the transition to obligate parasitism is linked to the relaxation of functional constraints on plastid genes. Our findings suggest that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxed functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. During the functional reduction process, the elevation of evolutionary rates reaches several new rate equilibria, possibly relating to the modified protein turnover rates in heterotrophic plastids. Our results have implications for the origin of plastids and their evolution. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The 2015–2017 drought in southwestern South Africa was the most severe in the last century. We show that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of this drought. This is a consequence of the strong sensitivity of the region to global warming. The probability of such a drought will increase by a factor of five to six under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5 [SSP2-4.5]) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5-8.5 [SSP5-8.5]). This highlights the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. Our results have implications for water management and food security in the region. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature has revolutionized our understanding of the structure of solids. However, the conditions under which these materials are formed are unknown. Here, we report the discovery of a hitherto unknown composition of icosahedral quasicrystal in a sample of red trinitite, the first test explosion of a nuclear bomb. The discovery of this material provides a link between the formation of quasicrystals in nature and in the laboratory. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophyll pigments is one of the most important and widespread biological pathways on Earth. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the so-called “cyclase reaction,” is the rate-limiting step in the biosynthesis of these pigments. The mechanism of this reaction has remained a mystery for more than 60 y. Here, we report the discovery of three classes of the cyclase reaction. These data provide a framework for understanding the evolution of this reaction. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in neurodegenerative diseases. Neuroinflammation is also known to be associated with autoimmune diseases. Neuroinflammation is a complex process that involves multiple cell types, including microglia, astrocytes, and neurons. In this study, we found that neuroinflammation was reduced in both the early and later stages of experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE) in microglia/macrophage-specific ASK1 knockout mice. We also found that ASK1 in astrocytes played a major role in exacerbating neuroinflammation. Our findings suggest that ASK1 in astrocytes plays a major role in exacerbating neuroinflammation. We propose that ASK1 in astrocytes as a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for neurodegenerative diseases and autoimmune diseases. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

California is currently in the midst of a record-setting drought. The drought began in 2012 and has led to acute water shortages, groundwater overdraft, critically low streamflow, and enhanced wildfire risk. We find that the probability of drought has increased in the past two decades. This increase is due to the fact that the probability of warm conditions has increased. We also find that the probability of drought has increased because of the increased likelihood of co-occurring precipitation deficits. These results are consistent with climate model experiments and suggest that anthropogenic warming is increasing the probability of co-occurring warm–dry conditions. This increase in the probability of drought is likely to be a major contributor to the increased frequency of drought in California.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability. The etiology of autism is so complicated because it involves the effects of variants of several hundred risk genes along with the contribution of environmental factors. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we identified a converging function of behavioral-learning-evoked Rac1-dependent forgetting in multiple autism-risk genes. This finding provides a framework for understanding the etiology of autism. It also provides a potential target for developing a treatment. This study may also provide a model system for understanding the role of memory in the brain.

This work is the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date. It also highlights individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. These findings have implications for the study of human cognition and behavior, and for the design of news content.

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ homeostasis. Dysregulation of the CRAC channel can lead to severe immune dysfunction and myopathy. Here, we identify mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and the pore-forming protein of the CRAC channel that lead to constitutive activation of the CRAC channel. These findings expand our understanding of the molecular function of the CRAC channel and suggest new therapies for patients with Stormorken syndrome. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Neurodegenerative diseases are characterized by the accumulation of misfolded proteins in the brain. These proteins aggregate and spread throughout the brain, causing damage to vulnerable neurons. However, the mechanisms underlying this spreading are not well understood. Here we show that the spread of a polyglutamine-expanded form of human huntingtin in Drosophila is non–cell-autonomous, and that it requires endocytosis. We also show that the spread of aggregates is important for the development of disease. These results have implications for the development of therapeutic strategies for neurodegenerative diseases. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Bats are the most diverse group of mammals and are increasingly recognized as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks. However, the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are not well understood. Here, we identified and characterized a protein that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of bats. This protein inhibits the antiviral immune response and facilitates viral infection. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting this immunosuppressant protein. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Cancer is a metabolic disease. Cancer cells have a high demand for one-carbon units, which are essential for cell growth. The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) converts serine into glycine and a tetrahydrofolate-bound one-carbon unit. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of SHMT. We show that this inhibitor blocks colon cancer tumor growth in mice. We also show that this inhibitor is effective in B-cell cancers, but is ineffective in other types of cancer. This suggests that B-cell cancers have a unique metabolic profile. Thus, this inhibitor may be useful in the treatment of B-cell cancers. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by mutations in a variety of proteins, including superaggregation-prone proteins. We show that the proteins that form inclusions in motor neurons are supersaturated even more than the native interaction partners of these proteins. This suggests that the inclusions are the result of a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. Our results may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for ALS. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold atoms. The photonic crystal system is predicted to produce exotic quantum phenomena, including suppressed spontaneous emission, atom–light interaction anisotropy, and atom–atom interactions. The system can be fabricated from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process. These devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The origin of the flowering plants is a major event in the evolution of the plant kingdom. The earliest flowering plants are poorly known. The study of Montsechia, a plant from the Cretaceous, opens the possibility that aquatic plants were common at an early stage of angiosperm evolution.

Parvoviruses are a group of DNA-containing viruses that cause a variety of diseases. The most common human parvovirus, B19V, is associated with a number of conditions, such as fifth disease in children and arthritis and arthralgias in adults. The evolution of B19V has been estimated to be rapid, with substitution rates being comparable to those of RNA viruses. Here we present the genomes of five individuals who lived between ∼0.5 and ∼6.9 thousand years ago. We find that B19V has been associated with humans for a long time. We also find that the recombination event that formed the most common B19V genotype occurred ∼5 thousand years ago. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Sea level is rising, and this rise is accelerating. These observations are consistent with the well-established scientific consensus that global warming is occurring and that it is largely caused by human activities. The rate of sea level rise is determined by the interplay of many factors, including the climate system, ocean circulation, and the solid Earth. This study provides a consistent and accurate estimate of the rate of sea level rise over the last 25 y. This estimate is consistent with the rate of sea level rise predicted by climate models. This study also provides a consistent and accurate estimate of the rate of sea level rise over the next 25 y. This estimate is consistent with the rate of sea level rise predicted by climate models.

Pain is a common and costly problem. We show that pain is increasing in the United States, with tomorrow’s elderly reporting less pain than today’s midlife. This is a mystery of American pain. We show that the erosion of working-class life is a likely explanation.

The structure of the enzyme-catalyzed transition state is a key to understanding enzyme mechanism. However, the structure of the enzyme-substrate complex is also important, as it is the starting point for the reaction. Here, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to characterize the structure of the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate. This intermediate is a defining species for pyridoxal-5′-phosphate–dependent enzymes that catalyze β-elimination and replacement reactions. The structure of the intermediate is used to understand the fate of the leaving group and the reaction pathway back to the preceding transition state. This detailed picture of the reaction pathway is key to understanding why one substrate is used in the reaction and not another. This work highlights the power of NMR-assisted crystallography for mechanistic enzymology. (Read more)

The development of effective antiviral treatments for Middle East Respiratory Syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is urgently needed. Here, we show that remdesivir, a nucleotide analog, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in a nonhuman primate model. This is the first report of the efficacy of remdesivir in a nonhuman primate model of coronavirus infection. Our results support the further development of remdesivir as a potential treatment for MERS-CoV. This may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The provision of nutrients to specific symbiotic microbes is a widespread strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their mutualistic associations. However, the mechanisms underlying this process are not well understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the activities of its luminescent symbionts through the strategic provision of a single glycan. This glycan is released by the host only at night, when the organ colonized by the symbionts is mature. The catabolism of this glycan is specifically required for the acidification of the organ, which enhances the luminescence of the symbionts. Our results suggest that the timing of the provision of specific nutrients may be a general strategy used by animals to regulate the activities of their associated microbes. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Suspension rates in US schools are high and rising. This study shows that teachers can be encouraged to adopt an empathic rather than punitive mindset about discipline. This change in mindset is associated with a reduction in suspensions. The intervention is scalable and can be implemented in schools.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage. However, the molecular mechanisms of how DNA alkylation affects the fidelity of transcription remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated the impact of alkylation on transcription. We found that the transcription reaction is sensitive to DNA alkylation. The transcription reaction is also sensitive to the regioisomeric DNA alkylation. The results from the present study provide important mechanistic insights into the molecular mechanisms of transcription. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe respiratory disease. To understand how sequential proteolysis contributes to MERS-CoV infection, we engineered MERS viruses with mutations that blocked the first proteolytic events. These viruses were less infectious to human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into other cell types. These findings suggest that the first proteolytic events expand virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection. Therefore, the first proteolytic events may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence. Understanding the determinants of MERS-CoV virulence may lead to the development of effective therapies and vaccines. Copyright © 2016. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The food system is a major contributor to global warming and other environmental degradation. The food choices of the population have a major impact on this. However, the food system is complex, and it is difficult to change people’s behavior. This study shows that it is possible to nudge people toward more sustainable diets. The results have implications for the design of interventions to change people’s behavior.

Cancer is a disease of the cell surface, and the surfaceome is the interface for the cell to interact with the extracellular space. We apply quantitative proteomics to reveal how the surfaceome is remodeled in a collection of six of the most prominent oncogenes. We find that each oncogene has somewhat different surfaceomes, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work is expected to be useful for drug and biomarker discovery in breast cancer. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs. This paper provides a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout. It also does not appear to increase either party’s vote share. Finally, vote-by-mail modestly increases overall average turnout rates. These findings support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media.

SARS-CoV-2 is the cause of the COVID-19 pandemic. The role of accessory proteins in the virus’s pathogenesis is unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2. This interface may be important for immune suppression and evasion. These results provide insight into the molecular basis of the severity of the disease caused by SARS-CoV-2. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Cerebral edema is a potentially life-threatening condition. The mechanisms underlying this condition are not well understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this is associated with an increase in the expression of the corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) and its receptor type 1 (CRFR1). We also show that CRFR1 is expressed by astrocytes and that CRF, acting through CRFR1, triggers signaling of cAMP/PKA, intracellular Ca2+, and PKCε in astrocytes. This leads to an up-regulation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and an increase in water influx into astrocytes. Finally, we show that this up-regulation of AQP4 is important for edema. These results provide a mechanism for the development of cerebral edema. This may help in the development of new therapeutic strategies. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The world is full of associations. We want to know which ones are strong. But we don’t want to know about the weak ones. This is the problem of selective inference. We describe some recent developments in selective inference and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis.

Endothelial cells (ECs) are the most important cell type in the blood vessel. However, the generation of ECs is difficult. In this study, we found that ets variant 2 (ETV2) can induce the generation of endothelial cells. This finding provides a new strategy for the generation of ECs.

The receptor tyrosine kinase (RTK) pathway is a major signaling pathway in the body. It is involved in a wide range of physiological and pathological processes. In the past few years, two new RTKs have been discovered. These are anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (LTK). They are involved in cancer and other diseases. We show that these two RTKs are involved in a physiological process in zebrafish. This is the first demonstration of a physiological role for these two RTKs. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a major public health problem. The molecular bases of T2D are still unknown. Herein, we show that STING is required for normal β-cell function. Indeed, STING deficiency decreased expression of β-cell function–related genes, contributing to impaired GSIS. Mechanistically, STING-βKO β-cells exhibited a loss of nuclear localization of Pax6, a transcription factor that is required for GSIS. These data establish a pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. This study provides a potential therapeutic target for T2D. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Influenza A viruses are the main cause of human influenza epidemics. They are also the origin of severe pandemics. The packaging of their genome is a key step in their replication. However, the molecular details of this process are unknown. Here, we identified a mechanism that favors the packaging of two viral RNA segments. This mechanism is not widely conserved among influenza A viruses. This might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. Our results have implications for the evolution of the influenza A virus. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Atherosclerosis is a chronic inflammatory disease that leads to cardiovascular events. The underlying mechanisms of atherogenesis are not fully understood. Here, we report a role of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) in the flow regulation of atheroprone endothelial phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions. Our results suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising athero-protective therapeutic strategy. This study may provide a new perspective for the development of antiatherosclerotic drugs. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Wildfire is a natural process that has shaped the landscape of the United States. However, human activities have expanded the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire. This expansion has increased the risk of wildfire to people, property, and the environment. We provide a comprehensive analysis of the role of humans in increasing the extent of wildfire. Our results highlight the need for increased management of human-started wildfires.

Urban change is a major topic of urban studies. However, the mechanisms of urban change are not well understood. In this paper, we introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: the density of college-educated adults, the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and the proximity to other attractive neighborhoods. These results provide support for three classical theories of urban change. Our method can be used to study the physical dynamics of cities. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Natural repellents are an ecological method of pest control. However, their molecular targets in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Zika virus (ZIKV) is a mosquito-borne flavivirus that has recently emerged as a cause of severe neurological complications. The current treatment options for ZIKV are limited to supportive care. Thus, there is a need for a better understanding of the dynamics of ZIKV within the host. Here we present a mathematical model of ZIKV dynamics in a nonhuman primate model. We use the model to estimate the basic reproductive number R0, the rate of viral production, and the time between cell infection and viral production. We also assess the effect of an antiviral treatment on the time to undetectable plasma viral load. Our results can be used to guide the development of future clinical trials. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Coral reefs are among the most valuable ecosystems on the planet. However, they are under severe pressure from global warming. The breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is one of the most dramatic consequences of this breakdown. We show that the catabolic degradation of amino acids is a key process in the early stages of the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis. This process is driven by the increased metabolic demand of the coral host during heat stress. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the stability of the coral holobiont and may ultimately help us to predict the fate of coral reefs in a changing world. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The intestinal epithelium is a complex barrier that protects the organism from the environment. In the absence of tumorigenesis, the epithelium is in a state of homeostasis. However, in the presence of tumors, the epithelium becomes dysfunctional. We show that the tumor-induced dysbiosis of the microbiome triggers a regenerative response, which in turn stimulates tumor growth. Our work identifies a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. It also highlights the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. Our findings have implications for the development of cancer therapies. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. The treatment of breast cancer with chemotherapy may lead to the emergence of breast cancer cells that are enriched for cancer stem cells. These cells may have enhanced capacity for tumor initiation and metastasis. In this study, we show that the expression of the orphan receptor ROR1 is increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy. We also show that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. These results may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for breast cancer. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The start of Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is often ascribed to a poleward shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies. However, this explanation is highly improbable. We show that a unique volcanic eruption series led to stratospheric ozone depletion, which plausibly explains the start of Southern Hemisphere deglaciation. This finding has implications for the interpretation of past climate changes and the role of stratospheric ozone depletion in the past.

Freshwater fisheries are an important source of food, recreation, and commerce. However, they are often overlooked in global assessments of ecosystem services. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. Our analysis also highlights the critical role of rivers in providing locally sourced, low-cost protein for the world’s poor. However, the spatial coincidence of productive fisheries and low food security underscores the high stakes for improving fishery management. Our data can be used to improve the inclusion of inland fisheries in environmental planning to protect both food security and species diversity.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge. The safety of aqueous Li-ion batteries is limited by the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The material delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. A full cell consisting of Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3/7O2 presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅ h ⋅ kg−1 as the maximum value in 21 m LiTFSA aqueous electrolyte, and 73% in capacity retention is achieved after 2,000 cycles. Furthermore, hard X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy study reveals that a protective surface layer is formed at the surface of the negative electrode, by which the high-energy and durable aqueous batteries are realized with Lix

The ability to regenerate is a defining feature of the adult nervous system. However, the molecular mechanisms that control this process are poorly understood. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway. This form of regeneration is triggered by physical lesion of the neuron, and it is enhanced by disrupting activity-dependent calcium signaling. These findings suggest that this form of regeneration may be a powerful platform for the discovery of genes involved in neuronal regeneration. Moreover, our study suggests that the adult nervous system may be more plastic than previously thought.

Recombination is essential for genome stability and the generation of genetic diversity. In eukaryotes, the process is initiated by the binding of proteins to specific DNA sequences. In this study, we describe the location of these binding sites in the genome of a flowering plant. We find that the distribution of these sites is remarkably similar to that in yeast and in mice. This suggests that the process of recombination initiation in eukaryotes may be conserved.

The resting brain is a dynamic system, with fluctuations in blood oxygen level-dependent (BOLD) signal reflecting the activity of a large number of brain regions. The functional connectivity of these regions is thought to reflect the organization of the brain. Here, we show that the metabolic organization of the resting brain is also reproducible and can be used to identify disease-related patterns. We also show that the organization of the brain is dynamic, and that this organization can be used to assess the functional status of the brain. These results have implications for the study of the brain in health and disease.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA. It is essential for translation initiation and is found on all mRNAs. Here we report the discovery of a second 5′ modification in eukaryotes, the nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) modification. We show that NAD-RNA is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs. NAD-RNA appears to be produced cotranscriptionally. This 5′ modification may have important functional consequences.

Metabolic memory is the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive diabetes therapy on the progression of microvascular complications. The molecular mechanisms underlying metabolic memory are not fully understood. Here, we show that epigenetic DNA methylation alterations at specific loci persist over time in people with diabetes. These epigenetic alterations are associated with glycemia and may contribute to the maintenance of metabolic memory. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer. The role of fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) in TNBC has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 is highly expressed in TNBC and is associated with poor prognosis. FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1. FSIP1 deficiency promotes autophagy, enhances AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreases mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restores the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Alcohol dependence is a major public health problem. The mechanisms underlying the development of the disease are not fully understood. In this study, we found that some alcohol-dependent subjects have altered gut permeability. This finding was associated with higher scores of depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving after 3 wk of abstinence. Moreover, the gut microbiota was altered in these subjects. These results suggest the existence of a gut–brain axis in alcohol dependence. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile chemicals. These volatiles are produced during ripening, and their content is highly variable among different tomato cultivars. The biosynthesis of these volatiles is not known. Here, we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all the detectable nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylations to produce these volatiles. This pathway is unique to tomato and likely contributes to the distinctive flavor of this fruit. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of tomato flavor. It also provides a model for understanding the biosynthesis of other nitrogenous volatiles in other species. (Read more)

Biodiversity is a key component of ecosystem functioning. However, the impacts of climate change on the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning have not been investigated together. We show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to temperature. As temperatures change, the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning shifts, meaning that more species are required to maintain ecosystem functioning under thermal stress. This result is driven by two processes. First, more diverse communities are more likely to contain species with thermal traits that maintain productivity under thermal stress. Second, the contribution of complementarity to the net biodiversity effect increases at high and low temperatures, indicating that changes in species interactions play a critical role in mediating the impacts of temperature change on the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. Our results highlight the importance of considering the impacts of climate change on the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning together. This will be critical for predicting the impacts of climate change on ecosystem services and the functioning of ecosystems. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for navigation. It is thought to encode the map of local space, but the organization of its neurons is not well understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of a large number of neurons in freely moving mice. We found that grid cells, which are essential for the formation of a map of local space, are organized separately from other neurons. This suggests that the formation of a map of local space might be a highly specialized process. Our findings also suggest that the formation of a map of local space might be a highly specialized process. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Flowering is a complex process that is regulated by environmental and internal signals. In this study, we show that the FT gene is not required for flowering of the host plant. Instead, FTs are able to move from the host to the dodder, where they interact with a dodder FD transcription factor to induce flowering. This study demonstrates that FTs can function as an important interplant flowering signal.
